dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until Thursday, then, Contessa Mio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she sits on the sofa)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Bialy, please, just a little. Just a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the Count hired you this morning, Rudolfo ... Watch the road ... Watch the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take my eyes off you.  How can I drive when you drive me mad. Mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she squeals with delight)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudolfo, you dirty pig!  Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upright)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  That's enough.  We'll do the rest on Thursday. (he reaches down and helps her off the couch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good girl. (leading her to the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always such fun to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until Thursday, then, you bawdy wench. HE SLAPS HER ON THE RUMP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh.  I love it.  Hold me, touch me. CUT TO BLOOM IN SHADOWS, AGHAST. BACK TO MEDIUM SHOT LITTLE OLD LADY AND BIALYSTOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday.  I'll see you Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll finish playing the Contessa and Rudolfo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Yes.  Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after that we'll play the Abduction and cruel rape of Lucretia ... And I'll play Lucretia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Thursday.  Will Thursday ever come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like clockwork. SHE STARTS TO DESCEND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall count the minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, my angel ... My angel! (calling after her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, touch me ... wait!  Hey, uh ... Lucretia, Lucretia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Angelcake, you forgot to give me the check.  Can't produce a play without money, ha, ha, ha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening her handbag and reaching inside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, the check, I had it with me all the time. SHE TAKES OUT THE CHECK AND HANDS IT TO HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's happening to me. I must be getting old. BIALYSTOCK TAKES CHECK AND READS IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it all right?  I made it out to cash.  You didn't tell me the name of the play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's fine.  Fine.  Good.  Good. Bye.  Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Til Thursday, my Darling, I shall count the minutes. SHE STARTS TO DESCEND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (descending)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta.  Ta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving check at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta.  Ta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He who signs a lease, must pay rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderer!  Thief!  How can you take the last penny out of a man's pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns back, shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to ... I'm a landlord!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to heaven)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, hear my plea.  Destroy him. He maketh a blight on the land. CUT TO LANDLORD ON THE WAY DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Lord)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pay attention.  He's crazy. CUT BACK TO BIALYSTOCK.  HE TURNS TO RE-ENTER HIS OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (biting his knuckle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nnnnn.  That hurt. (he sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to make another call. HE STARTS IN AND STOPS.  HE NOTICES BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bloom, quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been there all this time? BLOOM NODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you see and hear everything? BLOOM NODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what do you have to say for yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... uh ... ooooooops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?  What do you want? Why are you loitering in my hallway? Speak, dummy, speak!  Why don't you speak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared.  Can't talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Get a hold of yourself. Take a deep breath, let it out slowly and tell me who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathes deeply. Words tumble from his mouth as he exhales)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Leo Bloom, I'm an accountant, I'm from Whitehall and Marks, I was sent here to do your books and I'm terribly sorry I caught you with the old lady. (he has run out of breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Caught you with the old lady." Come in, Mr. Tact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're an accountant, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (timidly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then account for yourself!  Do you believe in God?  Do you believe in gold?  Why are you looking up old lady's dresses?  Bit of a pervert, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.  Never mind.  Do the books.  They're in that desk over there.  Top drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you condemn me without knowing all the facts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sir, I'm not condem ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.  I'm having a rhetorical conversation. (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How humiliating.  Max Bialystock. Max Bialystock. BIALYSTOCK SUDDENLY WHEELS AND SHOUTS AT BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who I used to be?  Max Bialystock!  The King of Broadway! Six shows running at once.  Lunch at Delmonico's.  Two hundred dollar suits.  Look at me.  Look at me now! I'm wearing a cardboard belt! HE RIPS THE BELT OFF AND HOLDS IT IN THE AIR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to have thousands of investors begging, pleading, to put their money into a Max Bialystock production.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at my investors now.  Voila! (gestures at pictures)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of little old ladies stopping off at Max Bialystock's office to grab a last thrill on the way to the cemetery. HE PUTS PICTURE BACK IN ITS PLACE.  LOOKS TOWARD BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have exactly ten seconds to change that disgusting look of pity into one of enormous respect.  One ... Two ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do the books!  Do the books! CUT TO BLOOM.  HE IS GREATLY RELIEVED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  Thank you. HE PLUNGES INTO HIS WORK. CUT TO BIALYSTOCK.  HE GOES TO WINDOW, LOOKS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Window's so filthy, can't tell if it's day or night out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over as camera follows Rolls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that.  A white Rolls Royce. That's it baby, when you got it, flaunt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koff, koff ... ahem, ahem ... harrumph ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume you are making those cartoon noises to attract my attention.  Am I correct in my assumption, you fish-faced enemy of the people? BLOOM IS WOUNDED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have hurt your feelings. BLOOM NODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, may I speak to you for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go!  You have fifty-eight seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, it seems ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have forty-eight seconds left. Hurry.  Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speedily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In looking at your books, I've discovered that ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-eight seconds, hurry, hurry, you're using up your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bialystock, I cannot function under these conditions. BIALYSTOCK CURIOUSLY EYES THE BLANKET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making me extremely nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?  A handkerchief? BLOOM QUICKLY BEGINS TO PUT AWAY HIS BLUE BLANKET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing ... nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's nothing, why can't I see it? BLOOM LEAPS UP IN HOT PURSUIT OF HIS BLANKET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrieking in panic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My blanket.  Give me my blue blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, don't panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clutching his blanket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry ... I don't like people touching my blue blanket.  It's not important.  It's a minor compulsion. I can deal with it if I want to. It's just that I've had it ever since I was a baby and ... and ... I find it very comforting. HE KISSES IT AND SHOVES IT INTO HIS POCKET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come here.  They all come here. How do they find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering his dignity)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bialystock ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Prince Mishkin, what can we do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is hardly a time for levity. I've discovered a serious error here in the accounts of your last play. BIALYSTOCK MOVES AROUND THE DESK TO EXAMINE THE LEDGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?  What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the backer's list you raised $60,000.  But the show you produced only cost fifty-eight thousand.  There's two thousand dollars unaccounted for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to a Turkish bath, who cares? The show was a flop.  What difference does it make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes a great deal of difference. That's fraud.  If they found out, you could go to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should they find out?  It's only two thousand dollars,  Bloom, do me a favor, move a few decimal points around.  You can do it. You're an accountant.  The word 'count' is part of your title.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's cheating!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not cheating ... It's charity. Bloom, look at me ... look at me! I'm drowning.  Other men sail through life.  Bialystock has struck a reef.  Bloom, I'm going under.  I am being sunk by a society that demands success, when all I can offer is failure.  Bloom, I'm reaching out to you.  Don't send me to jail.  Help!  Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear, oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  I'll do it.  I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Bloom.  I knew I could con you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's all right ... wha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Nothing.  Do it.  Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring over the accounts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's see, two thousand dollars. That isn't much.  I'm sure I can hide it somewhere.  After all, the department of internal revenue isn't interested in a show that flopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Right.  Good thinking.  You figure it out.  I'm tired.  I'm gonna take a little nap. (crossing to couch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake me if there's a fire. HE HURLS HIMSELF DOWN ONTO THE COUCH. CAMERA MOVES IN TO TIGHT SHOT OF BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's see, if we add these figures, we get ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh, heh, heh, amazing.  It's absolutely amazing.  But under the right circumstances, a producer could make more money with a flop than he could with a hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Yes.  It's quite possible. If he were certain the show would fail, a man could make a fortune. CUT TO BIALYSTOCK.  BY NOW HE IS HALFWAY ACROSS THE ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at a loss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you were saying.  Keep talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were saying that under the right circumstances, a producer could make more money with a flop than he could with a hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's quite possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep saying that, but you don't tell me how.  How could a producer make more money with a flop than with a hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's simply a matter of creative accounting.  Let us assume, just for the moment, that you are a dishonest man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assume away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's very easy.  You simply raise more money than you really need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done it yourself, only you did it on a very small scale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You raised two thousand more than you needed to produce your last play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?  What did it get me?  I'm wearing a cardboard belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhh!  But that's where you made your error.  You didn't go all the way.  You see, if you were really a bold criminal, you could have raised a million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the play only cost $60,000 to produce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  And how long did it run?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  You could have raised a million dollars, put on a sixty thousand dollar flop and kept the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if the play was a hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you'd go to jail.  If the play were a hit, you'd have to pay off the backers, and with so many backers there could never be enough profits to go around, get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha, aha, aha, aha, aha, aha!!  So, in order for the scheme to work, we'd have to find a sure fire flop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What scheme?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What scheme?  Your scheme, you bloody little genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.  No.  No.  I meant no scheme.  I merely posed a little, academic accounting theory.  It's just a thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloom, worlds are turned on such thoughts! BIALYSTOCK STARTS MOVING IN ON BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see, Bloom.  Darling, Bloom, glorious Bloom, it's so simple.  Step one:  We find the worst play in the world -- a sure flop.  Step two:  I raise a million dollars -- there's a lot of little old ladies in this world.  Step three:  You go back to work on the books.  Phoney lists of backers -- one for the government, one for us. You can do it, Bloom, you're a wizard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step four:  We open on Broadway and before you can say 'step five' we close on Broadway.  Step six:  We take our million dollars and fly to Rio de Janiero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ah, Rio, Rio by the seao, meo, myo, meo ... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (afraid of the scheme, afraid of the dance, afraid of Bialystock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bialystock.  No.  Wait.  Please. You're holding me too tight.  I'm an honest man.  You don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leading Bloom as he talks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Bloom, you don't understand. This is fate, this is destiny. There's no avoiding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the back of his head practically touching the floor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bialystock, not more than five minutes ago, against my better judgment, I doctored your books. That, sir, is the ultimate extent of my criminal life. BIALYSTOCK RAISES HIS FISTS TO THE HEAVENS IN DESPAIR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I fell on my keys. (he shifts slightly to make himself more comfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily hovering over Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miserable, cowardly, wretched little caterpillar.  Don't you ever want to become a butterfly?  Don't you want to spread your wings and flap your way to glory? BIALYSTOCK FLAPS HIS ARMS LIKE A HUGE PREDATORY BIRD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his eyes widened in terror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to jump on me. BIALYSTOCK STARES AT HIM INCREDULOUSLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to jump on me.  I know you're going to jump on me -- like Nero jumped on Poppea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonplussed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by now he is shrieking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poppea.  She was his wife.  And she was unfaithful to him.  So he got mad and he jumped on her.  Up and down, up and down, until he squashed her like a bug.  Please don't jump on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting and jumping up and down next to Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to jump on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolling away in terror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaaaa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoisting Bloom to his feet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get a hold on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (up on his feet and running for cover)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me!  Don't touch me! HE RUNS TO A CORNER OF THE ROOM.  TRAPPED!  HE TURNS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of?  I'm not going to hurt you!  What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hysterical.  I'm having hysterics.  I'm hysterical.  I can't stop.  When I get like this, I can't stop.  I'm hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wet!  I'm wet!  I'm hysterical and I'm wet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding his face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in pain!  And I'm wet!  And I'm still hysterical! BIALYSTOCK RAISES HIS HAND AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  No!  Don't hit.  It doesn't help.  It only increases my sense of danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do?  What can I do? You're getting me hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away from me.  You frighten me. (he indicates the sofa)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I'm way over here.  Is that better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little better, but you still look angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's this? (he smiles sweetly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Good.  That's nice.  That's very nice.  I think I'm coming out of it now.  Yes.  Yes.  I'm definitely coming out of it.  Thank you for smiling.  It helped a great deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (for want of something sensible)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know what they say, "Smile and the world smiles with you."  Heh, heh. (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man should be in a straight jacket. (to Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much, thank you.  But I am a little lightheaded.  Maybe I should eat something.  Hysterics have a way of severely depleting one's blood sugar, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They certainly do.  They certainly do.  Come, let me take you to lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you, Mr. Bialystock, but I ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense, nonsense, my dear boy.  I lowered your blood sugar, but least I could do is raise it a little. BLOOM LOOKS AT HIM SUSPICIOUSLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I promise you faithfully, I won't discuss that silly scheme to make a million dollars anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avanti! BLOOM GRACIOUSLY COMPLIES.  THEY EXIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bialystock, who is holding door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je vous empris. THEY TURN UP 45TH STREET AND HEAD TOWARD BROADWAY. BIALYSTOCK REACHES INTO HIS POCKET AND COUNTS HIS MONEY. LOOKS WORRIED.  SUDDENLY HIS FACE BRIGHTENS. WE SEE WHAT BIALYSTOCK SEES. CUT TO MURRAY THE BLINDMAN WORKING 45TH STREET. CAMERA BACK TO BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to his hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray, I'm going to lunch.  I took two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Bialy, that makes six eighty you owe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Don't worry.  You'll get it.  You'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping his way along)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't forget about it.  I need it.  Nobody understands.  I'm competing with giants.  The Greater New York Fund.  The March of Dimes. The Community Chest.  They're driving me out of business. BLOOM COMES DASHING BACK WITH HAT IN HAND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it, Mr. Bialystock. HE PROFFERS HAT TO BIALYSTOCK.  BIALYSTOCK TAKES IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Leo.  And call me Max. You know, I don't let everybody call me Max.  It's only people I really like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying it on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay ... Max!  And you can call me Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already have.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would you like to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Max, I don't know, Max.  What do you think, Max? BIALYSTOCK QUIETLY WINCES AT THE SURFEIT OF MAX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see ... it's such a beautiful day.  Why waste it indoors.  I've got it!  Let's go to Coney Island! We'll lunch at the sea shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coney Island??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Leo?  Don't you like Coney Island?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ... I love it.  I haven't been there since I was a kid.  But it's nearly two o'clock.  I really should be getting back to Whitehall and Marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense!  As far as Whitehall and Marks are concerned, you're working with Bialystock, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then stick with Bialystock! SWISH PAN CUT TO CONEY ISLAND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Custard Man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have another round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind now, sports?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind now, Leo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's loosening up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Let's see.  We've had chocolate, vanilla, banana - let's go green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Custard Man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pistachios, my good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not your good man, I happen to own this establishment. (he turns to fill the order)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's a big shot. (turns to Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Leo, are you having a good time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I think so.  I feel very strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  That's it.  Happy.  Well, whatta ya think of that.  Happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (licking his pistachio custard.  He is ecstatic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it.  I love it.  Get set. We're coming to another turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working, relentlessly working on Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloom, it can always be like this. Life can be beautiful.  Let me show you.  Stick with ... THEY HIT THE TURN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bialysto-o-o-o-ckk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money is honey.  Money is honey. Money can put soft things next to your skin.  Silk ... satin ... women. CLOSE-UP OF BLOOM'S EYES.  THEY WIDEN ON THE WORD "WOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if we're caught, we'll go to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing victory, he marshals his forces for the final assault)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're not in prison now? Living in a grey little room. Going to a grey little job.  Leading a grey little life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.  You're absolutely right.  I'm a nothing.  I spend my life counting other people's money -- people I'm smarter than, better than.  Where's my share? Where's Leo Bloom's share?  I want, I want, I want, I want everything I've ever seen in the movies! THE PARACHUTE BEGINS TO ASCEND.  WE FOLLOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming out of it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we're going up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet your boots, Leo.  It's Bialystock and Bloom -- on the rise. Upward and onward.  Say, you'll join me.  Nothing can stop us. BIALYSTOCK OFFERS HIS HAND TO BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting at the top of his lungs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it!  By God, I'll do it! BLOOM GRABS BIALYSTOCK'S HAND AND SHAKES IT FIRMLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where we belong, Leo.  On top of the world.  Top of the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oiiiiiii!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhhhhhh!!! BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM DROP OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, let's call it a night.  It's two in the morning.  I don't know what I'm reading anymore. PULL BACK TO TWO SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read, read.  We've got to find the worst play ever written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmnn.  "Gregor Samsa awoke one morning to find he had been transformed into a giant cock-a- roach."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling to himself as he reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, I've read this part. I'm reading plays I read this morning. HE GETS UP, STRETCHES, GOES TO WINDOW AND RAISES SHADE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good lord, it's morning.  Let's face it, we'll never find it. (he turns to face Bialystock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, tomorrow's another day. Today's another day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-camera.  Crazy little voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll never find it, eh?  We'll never find it, eh?  Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he does an insane little jig around the script)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't smell it when it's under your nose.  You can't see it when it's right before your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't feel it when it's in your hand, when it's in your pocket. CUT TO MEDIUM SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, what is it?  What are you doing?  What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what's happening. We've struck gold.  Not fool's gold, but real gold.  The mother lode.  The mother lode.  The mother of them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found a flop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flop, ha!  That's putting it mildly.  A disaster!  A catastrophe! An outrage!  A guaranteed-to-close- in-one-night beauty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is freedom from want forever. This is a house in the country. This is a Rolls Royce and a Bentley. This is wine, women and song and women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "SPRINGTIME FOR HITLER, A Gay Romp with Adolph and Eva in Berchtesgarten."  Fantastic! BACK TO TWO SHOT.  BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's practically a love letter to Hitler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ecstatic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't run a week!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run a week?  Are you kidding?  This play has got to close in the first act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wrote it? CUT TO AUTHOR'S NAME ON THE MANUSCRIPT:  By FRANZ LIEBKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is -- 415.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you want?  No one gets in the building unless I know who they want ... I'm the concierge.  My husband used to be the concierge. He's dead.  Now I'm the concierge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imperiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are seeking Mr. Franz Liebkind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the kraut.  He's on the top floor.  Apartment twenty-three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. THEY START INTO THE BUILDING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you won't find him there.  He's up on the roof with his birds.  He keeps birds.  Dirty, disgusting, filthy, lice-ridden birds.  You used to be able to sit out on the stoop like a person.  Not anymore. No sir.  Birds!  You get my drift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ... uh ... get your drift. Thank you, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a madam.  I'm a concierge. BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM ENTER THE BUILDING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to pigeon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilda, look ... look good ... Hilda, you're not looking.  Hilda, if he lives, I know you will find him. HE KISSES THE BIRD AND TOSSES IT SKYWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Bialystock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's wearing a German helmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a fierce whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh.  Don't say anything to offend him.  We need that play. (cups his hands to his mouth and calls up to the coop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz Liebkind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he speaks with a German accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vas never a member of the Nazi party.  I am not responsible.  I only followed orders.  Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Liebkind, wait.  You don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vhy do you persecute me?  My papers are in order.  I love my country. (he sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh, beautiful for spacious skies, For amber vaves of grain."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Liebkind, wait ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm a Yankee Doodle Dandy ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Liebkind, relax, relax, we're not from the government.  We came here to talk to you about your play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My play?  You mean, "Springtime For ... " you know who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vat about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We loved it.  We thought it was a masterpiece.  That's why we're here. We want to produce it on Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not, as you Americans say, dragging my leg, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at all sir, we're quite serious.  We want to produce your play. (he reaches into his attache case and displays a legal looking document)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the contracts right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh joy of joys!  Oh, dream of dreams!  I can't believe it. (he turns to the pigeons)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds, birds, do you hear?  Otto, Bertz, Heintz, Hans, Wolfgang, do you hear?  Ve are going to clear the Fuhrer's name.  Fly, fly, spread the words. HE OPENS THE CAGES AND SETS THE BIRDS FREE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing at the top of his lungs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Deutchland, Deutchland, uber alles, Uber alles in der velt." BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM LOOK AT EACH OTHER IN ALARM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing for all he's worth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Deutchland, Deutchland ... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Liebkind, Mr. Liebkind. LIEBKIND STOPS SINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People can hear you.

dialogues.speaker: OH.
dialogues.text: (he sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm a Yankee Doodle Dandy, Yankee Doodle is my ... " Listen, this is not place to talk.  Come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go to my flat.  An occasion like this calls for Schnapps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he hands glasses to Bialystock and Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bloom, Mr. Bialystock. Gentleman, with your permission, I would like to propose a toast to the greatest man that ever lived. Let us say his name quietly to ourselves.  The walls have ears. CUT TO TIGHT SHOT OF FRANZ LIEBKIND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a fervent whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adolph Hitler. (he downs drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sigmund Freud. (he downs drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max Bialystock. (he downs drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vas vit him a great deal, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished by the question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vit the Fuhrer, of course.  He liked me.  Out of all the household staff at Berchtesgarten, I vas his favorite.  I vas the only one allowed into his chambers at bedtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure.  I used to take him his hot milk and his opium.  Achhh, those were the days.  Vat good times ve had.  Dinner parties vit lovely ladies and gentlemen, singing und dancing.  You know, not many people knew about it, but the Fuhrer vas a terrific dancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, I never dreamed ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flies into an indignant rage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you were taken in by that verdampter Allied propaganda. Such filthy lies.  But nobody said a bad vord about Winston Churchill, did they?  Oh no, Vin Vit Vinnie! (he gestures V for victory)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churchill, vit his cigars and his brandy and his rotten paintings. Couldn't even say Nazi.  He would say Narzis, Narzis.  Ve vere not Narzies, ve vere Nazis.  But let me tell this, and you're getting it straight from the horse, Hitler vas better looking than Churchill, he vas a better dresser than Churchill, had more hair, told funnier jokes, and could dance the pants off Churchill!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swinging along)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly why we want to do this play.  To show the world the true Hitler, the Hitler you knew, the Hitler you loved, the Hitler with a song in his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, quick, the contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, sign here, Franz Liebkind. And make your dream a reality. HE HANDS LIEBKIND THE PEN.  LIEBKIND REFUSES IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  No.  How do I know I can trust you?  How do I know you vill present this play in the manner and spirit in vhich it vas conceived?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We swear it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough... Vould you be villing to take the Siegfried oath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  We would! INSERT:  CLOSE-UP BLOOM.  HE LOOKS WORRIED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  I will make the preparations. LIEBKIND LEAVES THE ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, I don't want to take any Siegfried Oath.  I don't know what it is, but I don't want to take it. We might end up in the German Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, you idiot.  He's a harmless nut.  Play along with him.  It's almost in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please to don your helmets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please to light your candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please repeat after me.  I solemnly swear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I solemnly swear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the sacred memory...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the sacred memory...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Siegfried...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Siegfried...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wagner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wagner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nietzche...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nietzche...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bismark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bismark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hindenburg...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hindenburg...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Graf Spee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Graf Spee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blue Max...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blue Max...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And last, but not least, Adolph... you know who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And last, but not least, Adolph... you know who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (saluting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil you know who!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spiritlessly saluting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil you know who!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Good.  Now ve sign the contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Good. (he hands Liebkind the pen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No.  Not in ink.  We'll desecrate the oath.  It must be done in blood. CUT TO BLOOM'S FACE.  IT IS A SILENT OI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingers, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ve vill sign vit this sacred qvill taken from the last chicken I served at Berchtesgarten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphantly whacking the contract with the back of his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is... in red and white! "Springtime For Hitler," signed, sealed and delivered. (he notices Bloom's dour expression)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm just not wearing this arm band.  I don't care how big the deal is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (placating him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, take it off, take it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to cab driver as he opens door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blue Gypsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about to enter cab with Bialystock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we going to the Blue Gypsy?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping Bloom from entering cab)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not going to The Blue Gypsy. I am going to The Blue Gypsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a rendez-vous with a lady of some means.  You see dear Bloom, phase one is complete, the play is ours.  We are now entering phase two -- the raising of the money. In the days to come, you will see very little of me, for Bialystock is launching himself into little- old-lady-land. (to cab driver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avanti! THE CAB SPEEDS AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to the success of your new play. BIALYSTOCK RAISES HIS GLASS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our play, my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, Bialy, did I wet you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think nothing of it, my dear.  A mere trifle.  A mere trifle.  Did you bring your checkbook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right here in my purse and I made it out just as you told me -- to cash.  That's a funny name for a play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think nothing of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking check from old lady)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Bialy, Bialy, tell me again. Tell me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edna, I swear on my life, you don't look a day over sixty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear the road!  Clear the road!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clutching Bialystock fiercely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Bialy, baby, go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly flustered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on with the concert!  Go on with the concert!  It's nothing.  Nothing. BIALYSTOCK STARES STRAIGHT AHEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bialystock, smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dirty man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tee hee, ha ha ha, ho ho, ooo, ooo, teehee hee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off camera, simultaneously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh, heh, heh.  Hah, hah, hah. THE CAR DRIVES OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping back to admire her work)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Bialy, how's it coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful, Alma, beautiful. (to the heavens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance!  Dance, slave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faster, faster, you dog.  Excite me, delight me.  Hold me, touch me. CUT TO CLOSE-UP OF BIALYSTOCK'S FACE AS HE DANCES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money is honey, money is honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing Bialystock contract)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Sarah Catheart.  She owns 50% of the profits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Eleanor Biddlecombe.  She also owns 50% of the profits. BIALYSTOCK SIGNS.  BLOOM PUTS THE NEXT ONE DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Virginia Resnick.  She also owns 50% of the profits. BIALYSTOCK SIGNS.  BLOOM TAKES ANOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Alma Wentworth.  She owns 100% of the profits. BIALYSTOCK SIGNS.  THEN LOOKS UP AT BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, what if this play is a hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the Department of Justice owns 100% of Bialystock and Bloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Bloom's thought makes him unhappy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OI.  I'm depressed.  Leo, do me a favor.  Open the safe.  I want to see the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself.  Inhales deeply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to buy a toy.  I worked very, very hard and I think I deserve a toy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quizzically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toy? DISSOLVE TO CLOSE-UP, FACE OF A GORGEOUS BLONDE, ULLA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a toy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  She's an adult, educational toy made in Sweden for children over fifty. BLOOM STARES AT HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop looking at me like that. She's not an indulgence.  She happens to be our new receptionist. She goes with our new surroundings. QUICKLY PAN POSH NEW WALL-PAPER, FURNISHINGS, ETC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ulla, I'd like you to meet my partner and associate, Mr. Leo Bloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got dag pa dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do. (to Bialystock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone mad?  A receptionist that can't speak English.  What will people say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll say, "Oooh, wah, wah, wah, ooh, ooh."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is she gonna do here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you.  Ulla, go to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya, sur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, it helps the day go by.  Ulla, okay.  Okay. ULLA STOPS, GOES TO PHONOGRAPH AND TAKES NEEDLE OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to desk.  Answer telephone. HE PICKS UP PHONE TO SHOW HER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bialystock and Bloom.  Bialystock and Bloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating to herself as she leaves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bialystock and Blum.  Bialystock and Blum.  Bialystock and Blum. Got dag pa dig.  Bialystock and Blum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bloom, opening up a box on his desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Blum, have a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. BIALYSTOCK TAKES AN ENORMOUS BLACK CIGAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Nothing.  Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pinching Bialystock's cheek)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Min Bialystock. ULLA LEAVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, as I was saying, maybe we should go easy on the spending.  I mean these offices and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Take it when you can get it! Flaunt it, baby, flaunt it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if something should... God forbid... go wrong, at least we could give them some of their money back.  It would look better in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop talking like that, you white mouse!  Nothing's going to go wrong. As a matter of fact, today I have taken steps to insure total disaster. At two o'clock we have an appointment with none other than Roger De Bris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (searching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger De Bris.  Roger De Bris.  Oh yes, the director.  Is he good... I mean bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger De Bris is the worst director that ever lived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he'll take the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if we ask him. BIALYSTOCK CONSULTS HIS WATCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  We'd better hurry.  We're late. BIALYSTOCK BUZZES.  ULLA ENTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call chauffeur.  Get car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Good.  We go Motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  We go. (he indicates Bloom and himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Blum go Motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No Motel.  Get car.  Get car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she leaves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get car.  Get car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to chauffeur)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Rudolfo. BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM CLIMB THE STEPS TO THE FRONT DOOR. BIALYSTOCK PUSHES THE DOORBELL.  WE HEAR CHIMES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't let anything he does or says upset you.  He's a little peculiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesssssss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Max Bialystock.  This is my associate, Mr. Bloom.  We have an appointment with Mr. De Bris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, you're expected.  Please come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.  I'm Carmen Giya, Mr. De Bris' private secretary.  Would you be so kind as to remove your shoes. BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM LOOK AT EACH OTHER BEWILDERED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White, white, white is the color of our carpets. BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM REMOVE THEIR SHOES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bloom indicating a rack of slippers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let's see, you're wearing grey. I would suggest the crimson. They're a little vivid, but your suit is so quiet. (to Bialystock, studying his mish mash attire)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you... Oh, take anything. Please follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from behind screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never get into this damned thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to De Bris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Messers Bialystock and Bloom, I presume.  Ha, ha, ha, forgive the pun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bialystock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What pun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a curt whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.  He thinks he's witty. (to De Bris)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to see you again, Roger. Did you get a chance to read "Springtime For Hitler?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remarkable.  Remarkable.  A stunning piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked, whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max!  He's wearing a dress. (his mouth remains open)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's a very important play. I, for one, never realized that the Third Reich meant Germany.  I mean it's drenched with historical goodies like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear, you're staring at my dress.  I should explain.  I'm going to the Choreographer's Ball tonight.  There's a prize for the best costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smugly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We always win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking in the mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not so sure about tonight.  I'm supposed to be the Grand Duchess -- I think I look more like Tugboat Annie.  What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No be cruel.  Be brutal.  Be brutal. Because heaven knows they will. Well, what do you think, Mr. Bloom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's... uh... it's nice and long... I mean, it's... uh... uh... where do you keep your wallet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gorgeous.  Absolutely gorgeous. You couldn't have picked a better color.  It brings out your eyes. Let's face it, Roger, that dress is you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his eyes flashing flirtatiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think it brings out my eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't tell a thing without your wig.  As far as I'm concerned, you're only half-dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummmm.  Well, if you're so worried about the wig, get it, o' wicked witch of the west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper to Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick, light his cigarette.  He likes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I meet you on a summer cruise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've... I've... never been on a cruise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, quel dommage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snidely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see we're getting acquainted. DE BRIS DROPS BLOOM'S HAND AND TURNS ON CARMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like to go back to teasing hair, big mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, do you mind if we talk a little business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, please, that's what we're here for. (to Carmen, who is adjusting the wig)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful, that hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this would be a marvelous opportunity for you, Roger.  Up to now, you've always been associated with musicals, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Dopey show-girls in gooey gowns.  Two-three-kick-turn!  Turn- turn-kick-turn!  It's enough to make you throw up!  At last a chance to do straight drama!  To deal with conflict, with inner truth.  Roger De Bris presents history.  Of course, I think we should add a little music.  That whole third act has got to go. They're losing the war.  It's too depressing.  We'll have to put something in there. (gripped by his vision)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaahghhh!  I see it!  A line of beautiful girls, dressed as Storm Troopers, black patent leather boots, all marching together... Two-three-kick-turn!  Turn-turn- kick-turn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's genius.  That's genius. Roger, I think I speak for Mr. Bloom and myself when I say that you're the only man in the world who can do justice to SPRINGTIME FOR HITLER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in one rush)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  This is a very big decision.  It might effect the course of my entire life.  I'll have to think about it.  I'll do it. DE BRIS EXTENDS HIS HAND.  BIALYSTOCK SHAKES IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Carmen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on the phone.  Send out a casting call.  Call every agent in town.  I want to see everybody. Everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking for the least likely Hitler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, what about that one?  The fat Hitler on the right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I rather fancy that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad.  Not bad.  What do you think, Franz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very emotional)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I don't know.  For some strange reason, I'm deeply moved. (he wipes away a tear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting to his feet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is bedlam, bedlam.  We must have some order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clapping his hands for attention)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will all the dancing Hitlers please wait in the wings.  We're only taking the singing Hitlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Packard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Arthur.  Tell us something about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a strangulated tenor's voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the lead tenor of the Albuquerque Opera Company for two seasons.  I just finished a road tour of STUDENT PRINCE.  And last season I was up for the lead in the Broadway production of Circus Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to sing for us Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soliloquy from CAROUSEL. FROM THE PIT THE PIANO PLAYS A FOUR BAR INTRODUCTION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boy Bill will be strong and as tall as a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. ARTHUR SHRUGS AND LEAVES THE STAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Jason, what have you been doing lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in basso profundo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the last sixteen years, I've been touring with "Naughty Marietta."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  And what are you going to sing for us, Jason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Stout-hearted Men." BEGINNING OF "STOUT-HEARTED MEN" MONTAGE. THERE IS A SHORT PIANO INTRODUCTION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Give me some men Who are stout-hearted men Who will fight for the right they adore."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-camera voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaaank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Show me some men Who are stout-hearted men And I'll soon show you ten thousand more."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-camera voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaaank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Shoulder to shoulder and bolder and bolder They grow as they march to the war."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice off camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaaank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There is nothing in this world can halt or mar our plan."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice off camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "When stout-hearted men Will get together man to man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice off camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaaank you. CUT TO CARMEN GIYA ON STAGE.  IT IS NOW EMPTY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's enough Hitlers for one day.  Maybe we'll get lucky tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think out of all those Hitlers you could find just one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the same thing in Germany. We looked for years before we found the right Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: WE ARE NOT SURE WHETHER IT IS A YOUNG MAN OR A YOUNG WOMA
dialogues.text: (LORENZO ST. DU BOIS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this where they're auditioning Boomerang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying him coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid you've wandered into the wrong theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself, as he starts to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, freaked out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaping to his feet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!  This is Boomerang.  This is Boomerang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bialystock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hear him.  What have we got to lose? (to LSD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorenzo Saint DuBois.  But everybody calls me LSD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done, LSD?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months, I'm out on probation, but it's cool now, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean in show business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, in show business.  Well, let's put it this way, my next job will be my debut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do best?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, I can't do that here, that's what they put me away for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sing.  Sing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, that's where they put me, Sing-Sing.  How'd you know that, you been up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little hysterical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sing a song!  Just sing a song!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a little thing I think you're going to see on the charts any day.  I wrote it last night in my sleep.  It's a Hindu Zen Folk Rock Ballad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's our Hitler!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (howls of despair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaaaat???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz, don't you see, Hitler was a man of his time.  This is a man of his time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he has long hair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at the outside, look at the inside.  It's the inner Hitler we're after.  The young beautiful Hitler, who danced his way to glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he has been studying LSD intensely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be an exciting piece of off- beat casting.  Of course, we'd have to do something about that coiffure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's so crazy, he's so sloppy, he's so... so... American!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franz, trust me.  I promise I won't let you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, but remember, if you damage the Fuhrer's reputation, I kill you.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO MARQUEE OF BROADWAY THEATRE. MARQUEE READS
dialogues.text: OPENING TONIGHT - SPRINGTIME FOR HITLER.  Directed by ROG DE BRIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a silver-haired gentleman in his late fifties)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Max, I hope it's a big hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bite your tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little old lady)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna do it this time, Bialy, I just know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you lose your bloomers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another old lady)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My prayers go with you, Bialy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God Forbid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bialystock and Bloom, very seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is a very momentous moment. HE CLICKS HIS HEELS AND SHAKES HANDS WITH EACH OF THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bloom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck. (to Bialystock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a mad gleam in his eye)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, New York.  Tomorrow, the world! HE TURNS TRIUMPHANTLY AND ENTERS THE THEATRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check your hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much for Nutsy Fagin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nudging Bialystock, whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes the Times Drama Critic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch closely, as Bialystock drives the last nail into the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always delighted to see the gentlemen of the press.  There you are, sir.  Two on the aisle, compliments of the management. (he smiles unctuously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haughtily accepting tickets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Here, wait a minute. There seems to be some mistake. There's a hundred dollar bill wrapped around these tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conspiratorially)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no mistake.  Enjoy the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bialystock, just what do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm bribing you.  And if you play ball, there's a lot more where that came from. BIALYSTOCK WINKS AND SAUNTERS OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blustering with rage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I... I... How dare he!  I've never been so insulted in my life! The gall of the man!  The incredible gall of the man!  I'll fix his wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check your hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning like a Cheshire cat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh, heh, heh.  He'll kill us. FROM INSIDE THE THEATRE, WE HEAR THE OVERTURE BEGINNING. LIGHTS IN THE LOBBY BLINK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, they've started the overture. BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM ENTER THE THEATRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually shrieking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Max, this is it!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, in two hours our worries will be over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Germany was having trouble, What a sad, sad story. Needed a new leader To restore its former glory. Where, oh, where was he, Who could that man be, We looked around, And then we found, The man for you and me, And now its...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Springtime for Hitler," etc. CUT TO AUDIENCE.  NUMBER ON STAGE CONTINUES. CLOSE-UP OF MAN AND WOMAN ON AISLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is shocking! CUT TO ANOTHER AREA OF AUDIENCE.  ANOTHER COUPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outrageous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhhhh, it's going better than I expected. THE COUPLE COMES ABREAST OF BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to man as they exit theatre)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, talk about bad taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he chuckles as they leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, let us repair to the bar across the street.  I don't want to be caught here during intermission. We'll be stoned to death. THEY LINK ARMS AND MERRILY MARCH OUT OF THE THEATRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Springtime for Hitler, Is Springtime for Goering, Is Springtime for Goebbels, Is Springtime for Himmler, Is Springtime for you and me!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er liebt mir.  Er liebt mir nicht. Er liebt mir. (the last petal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er liebt mir nicht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to LSD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Du liebt mir nicht!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting vehemently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lieb you baby, I lieb you.  You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you lieb me, why are you leaving me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, I can't spend all my time with you.  I took an oath, baby, Deutschland uber alles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Hitler?  I get it!  It's a put-on. CUT TO WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Harry, he's funny. NOW THERE IS A MAD RUSH TO REGAIN THEIR SEATS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to the one and only performance of "Springtime for Hitler."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Innkeeper, innkeeper, another round of drinks here.  As a matter of fact, a round of drinks for everybody in the place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think, yesterday I was a meaningless little accountant -- and today, I am the producer of a Broadway flop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To failure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To failure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blushing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you!  It's very kind of you. (raises his glass and downs his drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Duke of Windsor could give up the Throne of England for the woman he loved, why can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's different.  I'm a tyrant, baby. AUDIENCE LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (becoming slightly unhinged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, why does he keep saying baby? I didn't write baby.  The Fuhrer never said baby.  Vat is it vit this baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shut up!  I'm the author. You're just the audience.  I outrank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bartender, bartender, another drink for myself and my associate, Mr. Bloom.  And don't forget our good- natured inebriate over there. DRUNK TIPS HIS HAT GRACIOUSLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eternally grateful.  Sincerely yours, Oliver Wendell Drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raises his glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stumped)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To... toast!  I love toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smacking his glass down on the bar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'll take the lead and I want you right behind me all the way! One... two... three! (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "By the light,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "By the light, by the light,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Of the silvery moon,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Of the silvery mooooon,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I want to croon,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He wants to croon, he wants to croon,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To my honey I'll croon,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He's gonna croon love's tune,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Honeymoon,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Honeymoon, honeymoon,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Keep a shining in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intermission!  Quick, hide your face.  They'll tear us to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad-lib)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Scotch on the rocks," "Bourbon and soda." "Two martinis." "Whiskey sour."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her escort)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, so far that's about the funniest thing I've ever seen on Broadway. BIALYSTOCK AND BLOOM LOOK AT EACH OTHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never laughed so much in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his friend)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hysterical, absolutely hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd split my sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, don't panic.  There are a lot of plays on this street. They are not necessarily talking about "Springtime For Hitler."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I never in a million years thought I'd ever love a show called "Springtime For Hitler."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bialy, you sly fox, you've done it. It's a smasheroo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a daze)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smasheroo.  Smasheroo. THE CROWD STARTS TO LEAVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd better hurry back.  I don't want to miss one minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to think... Got to think... Got to think... Got to think... Got to think... CUT TO BLOOM AT THE BAR, FROZEN, STARING STRAIGHT AHEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
